ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Amrit Foundation of India, a registered society, is an initiative to make the world a more inclusive place especially for children with intellectual challenges. It aims at the development and well-being of all Indians, irrespective of their religion, race, caste, creed or gender so that they may individually and collectively reach their full potential. It also seeks to develop and support institutional mechanisms as well as collaborate with other organizations to further its goals of equity and inclusion. The Little Peepul Tree, a flagship program of Amrit Foundation of India, is a unique web based portal which is an initiative to support those who deal with intellectual challenges. It is an information bank for Children in Need and their caregivers. We work as a â€˜clearing houseâ€™ that collects, collates and distributes useful knowledge, and advocates with state and non-state entities for supportive policies, laws, actions and financial assistance.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: ANANT or An Association for Nascent Art and Natural Theatre was registered on 3 January, 1989. In the last twenty one years, ANANT has many achievements to its credit. First and foremost, it has established itself as a leading exponent of childrenâ€™s theatre in Delhiâ€”producing plays by and for children; conducting workshops for young, teachers and educators both in schools and communities; working in villages, slums and resettlement colonies; and linking theatre and arts to education and pedagogy. Plays created by ANANT are unique, using culture friendly traditions like play-rhymes, folk narrative traditions like kathavachan and kissa-goi, visual communication through puppetry and pat-katha; and the techniques of storytelling. Some of its well known plays in Hindi are Gadbadjhala (Topsy Turvy), Raja ki Khoj (In Search of a King), Kisse (A Tale of Tales), Chhutti (Freedom), Gopi Gawaiya Bagha Bajaiya (Gopi the Singer Bagha the Drummer) and Liyaram Diyaram. Most of these are original plays, created through workshops with ANANT actors. Many of these plays have participated in numerous festivals in India and abroad. Gadbadjhala, based on collection of rhymes from the Hindi belt, was published by education department of the University of Delhi as resource book with audio support in the form of a cassette. ANANT is in the process of editing some of its original plays for publication. ANANT has conducted innovative school projects by way of using theatre for theme exploration, and subsequent theatrical presentations involving the entire school. The school projects of Presentation Convent and Swai Man Singh School of Jaipur are worth mentioning. ANANT has also conducted an experimental project called Heritage Theatre in the National Museum wherein Harrapa Gallary was explored by educationally marginalised street children with a production and exhibition as the end result. ANANT has also produced adult plays from time to time. Two such productions in Bengali are considered by many critics as unique contributionsâ€”Kathokatay Agomani (Homecoming) and Manasa Katha (Legend of Manasa). Whether in children theatre or adult plays, ANANT puts lot of emphasis on research and originality. ANANT has participated in national and international festivals, exchange programmes, and had conducted workshops and submitted papers for seminar all over. Some of these are: Jashne Bachpan and Bharat Rang Mahotsav organised by the National School of Drama in New Delhi, Folk Festival of Eastern Zonal Cultural Centre, Surya Festival in Cochin, DALA Festival in Seoul, and AYA Exchange programme in Kuala Lumpur. ANANT is one of the founding members of ASSITEJ India, the gateway national centre of ASSITEJ International which is spread over 80 countries, connecting thousands of theatre groups and persons working in the specialised area of theatre for children and young people. Following the establishment of ASSITEJ India in 2004, ANANTâ€™s director, Dr. Ashish Ghosh, has been invited to participate in ASSITEJ World Congress in Montreal, International Directorsâ€™ Seminar in Hamburg, and as International Observer in NEW VOICE/NEW VISION project in Kennedy Center of Washington DC. ANANT is poised for major events, both national and international, in 2011.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: â€¢ Ms.Rita Panicker was awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award 2016 by the National Association of Professional Social Workers in India for her distinct contribution in the domain of child rights, especially street & working children at the 4th Indian Social Work Congress. â€¢ Rita Panicker honoured by Shri Amitabh Bachan in the new Star Plus show Aaj Ki Raat Hai Zindagi 2015 â€¢ Vanitha Woman of the Year 2013 by the Malayala Manorama group. Award instituted to acknowledge the work done by Malayali women to serve our society â€¢ IGSSS Shrestha Puruskar,2011, by the Indo Global Social Service Society in New Delhi for pioneering work in bringing significant changes in the lives of street and working children. â€¢ Nominated in 2009 for the "Right Livelihood Award" and was one of the finalists for the award. â€¢ Women of Social Work Excellence by Manava Seva Dharmasamvardhani Charitable Trust for Social Service Consciousness, Chennai, on 27 February 2002. â€¢ Childrens Development Khazana started by Butterflies in 2001 received the Second Prize in the 2006 Global Development Network Award for the Most Innovative Development Project. This award is given to the institution whose ongoing project embodies a fresh approach to an important development need and holds the greatest promise for benefiting the poor in developing and transition countries. Criteria include the degree of innovation and the potential for broad application of the project in other countries. â€¢ The Ramachandran Ikeda Award 1999 was conferred on Butterflies in appreciation of their work in education, healthcare and recreation of street and working children. The award was conferred on Butterflies for following Gandhian philosophy of education i.e. schools should be living school where children are taught life skills education, to respect work especially those who work with their hands and to respect and accept all irrespective of language, religion or caste.

Butterflies works in 13 contact points in Delhi and reaches out to more than 2,000 children on a daily basis.

Butterflies Resilience Center (RC) is a short stay home where Children who are rescued require temporary care and protection during the process of restoration and rehabilitation. This will be provided at RC which is being constructed for temporary care centre for children in need of care

The Health Cooperative. Child Health Co-operative (CHC) is a unique initiative started in 1995. Key objectives of CHC is to promote safe and healthy living among children and communities. The cooperative has regular workshops where the children deliberate on health, nutrition and environment issues and gain knowledge regarding prevention of diseases and the importance of nutrition and a clean environment.

Childlne 1098 is a 24x7 telephone outreach service for children in need of care and protection being implemented by the Ministry of Women and Child Development, Government of India in partnership with NGOs. Butterflies is managing the services in 2 Districts of Delhi and at Nizamuddin Railway Station. The Ministry provides resources through Childline India Foundation.

Mobile Learning Centre (School) Dehradun. Mobile Education is the “Gateway of Knowledge” that reaches out to the children in remotest areas through personalized human touch. This innovative initiative seeks to strengthen the existing efforts of Government to bring out of school children in the education net by providing quality education till the last mile. The program is being implemented through close collaboration with State Education Departments in Delhi and Uttarakhand.

Providing temporary care and protection to children in need of care and protection in Resilience Centre (temporary care Centre for children). Some part of the funds is also used for the Butterflies School of Culinary and Catering where street adolescents are trained in culinary and catering along with a stipend to cover their travel expenses.

Establishment and management of Child Health and Sport Cooperatives as safe, supportive and participatory spaces for children to learn life skills. Awareness sessions are also held along with training and sports activities with children to improve their knowledge about mental and physical wellbeing. Supporting parents to increase their knowledge and understanding about the importance of mental health and emotional wellbeing of children. Conduct researches for creating knowledge

To highlight this widespread yet hidden issue of sexual exploitation of boys, a campaign titled Blue Umbrella Campaign will be launched by Family for Every Child, UK and Butterflies in India a member of FFEC and National Alliance of Grassroots NGOs on April 16 2021. Mobile Education Programme: We are providing education to street-connected children who are not able to join regular school to continue their education. They are either migrants or casual labourers not having a permanent place to stay. So we provide education through our mobile education van, which goes to the place where these children live and work (make it as a contact point). On seeing the van children assemble together for their lessons. The mobile school is well equipped with a library
Funds from this programme are used to provide teaching and learning support to street children to enrol
